citations.narrative:
An enclosure did not contain an animal securely. On 9/24/2024, the applicant states that the gate to the outside run of one
enclosure broke and allowed an animal to enter the adjacent enclosure resulting in a fight and injuries to another animal.
Adult female English Mastiff (#2153) sustained wounds to a large portion of the back and sides. The animal was treated
by the Attending Veterinarian and the areas where the injuries occurred do not have hair. The applicant states that the
metal hook that holds the gate clip broke resulting in the gate to open but they have since fixed the gate. Enclosures that
do not properly contain animals can cause pain, distress, and injury. Correct by ensuring that enclosures are constructed
and maintained so that they contain the dogs securely at all times.

The applicant does not maintain complete medical records for all animals. Medical records indicate that a litter of
approximately 10-week-old English Mastiff puppies (#2947,2929,2948,2923,2934) did not have any history of receiving
Distemper and Parvovirus vaccines. The applicant states that the animals had received these vaccines and were up to
date but they did not record that information in the medical record.
Failure to maintain adequate medical records may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the animals
are receiving adequate veterinary care. Complete medical records must be maintained and include the names of all
vaccines and treatments administered and the dates of administration. Correct by documenting all treatments given and
ensure that medical records are complete and contain the required information.

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats.
citations.narrative:
A transport enclosure failed to contain an animal. In the fall of 2024, the applicant states that an adult female English
Mastiff (#2157) was able to escape out the front door of their enclosure during transport but was recovered. Enclosures
that do not properly contain animals can cause pain, distress, and injury. Correct by ensuring that the primary transport
enclosure is strong enough to contain the dogs securely and comfortably and is able to withstand the normal rigors of
transportation.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by June 6, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
